application.ref: A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

text.p: This is a PDF file of an article that has undergone enhancements after acceptance, such as the addition of a cover page and metadata, and formatting for readability, but it is not yet the definitive version of record. This version will undergo additional copyediting, typesetting and review before it is published in its final form, but we are providing this version to give early visibility of the article. Please note that, during the production process, errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.This is a PDF file of an article that has undergone enhancements after acceptance, such as the addition of a cover page and metadata, and formatting for readability, but it is not yet the definitive version of record. This version will undergo additional copyediting, typesetting and review before it is published in its final form, but we are providing this version to give early visibility of the article. Please note that, during the production process, errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.

Several investigations have been done on solar energy in the past years. The utilization of fossil fuels will be restricted due to fewer resources as well as environmental concerns. Researchers are looking for other possible energy sources because of these concerns. The principal attention for energy-saving in thermal collectors is an improvement in heat transfer performance. Solar thermal energy has been widely employed for power generation, chemical processing, and thermal heating applications because of its sustainable nature and fewer emissions [1,2].Several investigations have been done on solar energy in the past years. The utilization of fossil fuels will be restricted due to fewer resources as well as environmental concerns. Researchers are looking for other possible energy sources because of these concerns. The principal attention for energy-saving in thermal collectors is an improvement in heat transfer performance. Solar thermal energy has been widely employed for power generation, chemical processing, and thermal heating applications because of its sustainable nature and fewer emissions [1,2].

Heating and cooling of common fluids such as water, ethylene glycol (EG), and oil are regarded as critical challenges for heat transfer applications including, power production, transportation and generation, chemical methods, and many more but due to its low thermal conductivity, affecting heat flux mechanisms, such as cooling [3], material handling and solar thermal collectors [4,5]. Because of the suitable properties of EG, it is used for heat transfer applications such as HVAC devices and solar collectors as well as internal combustion engines. By enhancing the heat transfer rate, the processing time will be reduced for industrial applications and developments in energy savings will be improved [6]. To develop the progress in thermal conductivity for conventional fluids, Choi [7] in 1995 introduced nanofluids by suspending nano-sized metallic and non-metallic particles (1-100 nm) in the base fluid.Heating and cooling of common fluids such as water, ethylene glycol (EG), and oil are regarded as critical challenges for heat transfer applications including, power production, transportation and generation, chemical methods, and many more but due to its low thermal conductivity, affecting heat flux mechanisms, such as cooling [3], material handling and solar thermal collectors [4,5]. Because of the suitable properties of EG, it is used for heat transfer applications such as HVAC devices and solar collectors as well as internal combustion engines. By enhancing the heat transfer rate, the processing time will be reduced for industrial applications and developments in energy savings will be improved [6]. To develop the progress in thermal conductivity for conventional fluids, Choi [7] in 1995 introduced nanofluids by suspending nano-sized metallic and non-metallic particles (1-100 nm) in the base fluid.

Different nanofluids have been developed by many researchers for effective heat transfer performance of various metals and metal oxides [8]. The characteristics of nanomaterials affect the increased surface area and quantum effects, which change physical, chemical, optical, mechanical and electrical properties behavior [9]. Nanofluids exhibit high thermal properties, long-term stability, minimum aggregation, low pumping power, and homogeneity because of nanoparticles small size and large surface area and investigated in various applications [10,11]. The preparation of stable nanofluids is important and most investigators have focused on nanofluids stability with no decisive conclusions [12]. Many investigations have been conducted by scholars on nanofluids thermophysical characteristics and stability [13][14][15], but it J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f is inadequate. So, more research is required to study the consequences and mechanisms of different parameters on nanofluids.Different nanofluids have been developed by many researchers for effective heat transfer performance of various metals and metal oxides [8]. The characteristics of nanomaterials affect the increased surface area and quantum effects, which change physical, chemical, optical, mechanical and electrical properties behavior [9]. Nanofluids exhibit high thermal properties, long-term stability, minimum aggregation, low pumping power, and homogeneity because of nanoparticles small size and large surface area and investigated in various applications [10,11]. The preparation of stable nanofluids is important and most investigators have focused on nanofluids stability with no decisive conclusions [12]. Many investigations have been conducted by scholars on nanofluids thermophysical characteristics and stability [13][14][15], but it J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f is inadequate. So, more research is required to study the consequences and mechanisms of different parameters on nanofluids.

Mono nanoparticles due to its large surface energy and specific area are prone to reunite and therefore result in sedimentation when dispersed in the base fluid [16], which shifted the focus of the research community towards hybrid nanofluids. Hybrid nanofluids were introduced in the last few years to surpass some challenges that affect the performance of nanofluids [17]. Nanocomposite materials comprised of two or more nanomaterials suspended in the base fluids for the preparation of nanofluids, and it is considered an essential feature of the fastest-growing areas in nanotechnology. The researchers in the areas of engineering and materials science are paying more attention to hybrid nanofluids. This leads to fluids having adjusted properties with a trade-off between the properties of individual nanoparticles used to make a hybrid. In some cases, nanofluids of hybrid nanoparticles show better stability and thermophysical properties as with single nanoparticles. Hence, hybrid nanofluids are having a higher edge than mono nanofluids. As an example, ceramic materials such as Alumina has excellent stability and chemical inertness, which are some of the excellent properties it has but shows a lower thermal conductivity when compared to metallic nanoparticles. However, reactivity and stability are two crucial factors that should be considered for nanofluid applications [18]. These hybrids include various kinds of nanoparticle, several base fluids, or nanocomposites [19][20][21]. The accurate knowledge of thermophysical characteristics is essential to estimate the thermal system performance operating with nanofluids. These characteristics are entirely dependent on nanoparticle concentration suspended and consistently dispersed in the base fluids. The stable hybrid nanofluids have developed enhanced thermal conductivity and significant results in renewable energy, capacity, and a decrease in the cost of the thermal system due to an increase in thermal systems efficiency in addition to the reduction in hazardous emissions [22]. Suresh et al. [23,24] examined improvement in thermal conductivity by preparing Al 2 O 3 -Cu hybrid nanofluids and computed the convective heat transfer for Al 2 O 3 -Cu nanofluid and about 14% heat transfer improvement was observed. Nine et al. [25] prepared Al 2 O 3 -MWCNTs hybrid nanofluids and analyzed their thermal properties for 1-6% particle loading concentrations. Madhesh et al. [26] observed the overall J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f heat transfer coefficient of copper-titania nanocomposite, and it was seen to be improved for different volume concentrations by more than 50%.Mono nanoparticles due to its large surface energy and specific area are prone to reunite and therefore result in sedimentation when dispersed in the base fluid [16], which shifted the focus of the research community towards hybrid nanofluids. Hybrid nanofluids were introduced in the last few years to surpass some challenges that affect the performance of nanofluids [17]. Nanocomposite materials comprised of two or more nanomaterials suspended in the base fluids for the preparation of nanofluids, and it is considered an essential feature of the fastest-growing areas in nanotechnology. The researchers in the areas of engineering and materials science are paying more attention to hybrid nanofluids. This leads to fluids having adjusted properties with a trade-off between the properties of individual nanoparticles used to make a hybrid. In some cases, nanofluids of hybrid nanoparticles show better stability and thermophysical properties as with single nanoparticles. Hence, hybrid nanofluids are having a higher edge than mono nanofluids. As an example, ceramic materials such as Alumina has excellent stability and chemical inertness, which are some of the excellent properties it has but shows a lower thermal conductivity when compared to metallic nanoparticles. However, reactivity and stability are two crucial factors that should be considered for nanofluid applications [18]. These hybrids include various kinds of nanoparticle, several base fluids, or nanocomposites [19][20][21]. The accurate knowledge of thermophysical characteristics is essential to estimate the thermal system performance operating with nanofluids. These characteristics are entirely dependent on nanoparticle concentration suspended and consistently dispersed in the base fluids. The stable hybrid nanofluids have developed enhanced thermal conductivity and significant results in renewable energy, capacity, and a decrease in the cost of the thermal system due to an increase in thermal systems efficiency in addition to the reduction in hazardous emissions [22]. Suresh et al. [23,24] examined improvement in thermal conductivity by preparing Al 2 O 3 -Cu hybrid nanofluids and computed the convective heat transfer for Al 2 O 3 -Cu nanofluid and about 14% heat transfer improvement was observed. Nine et al. [25] prepared Al 2 O 3 -MWCNTs hybrid nanofluids and analyzed their thermal properties for 1-6% particle loading concentrations. Madhesh et al. [26] observed the overall J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f heat transfer coefficient of copper-titania nanocomposite, and it was seen to be improved for different volume concentrations by more than 50%.

Researchers have focused on properties of magnetite (Fe 3 O 4 ) nanofluids, have attracted attention because of the wide range of purposes in the energy disciplines such as CO 2 capture [27] and thermal absorption systems and employed for direct absorption in collectors for solar radiation [28]. Wide-ranging photon absorption cross-section, and powerful intermolecular bonds, economical, and environmentally friendly are the main characteristics of Fe 3 O 4 . Fertman et al. [29] studied hydrocarbon-based magnetic fluids, including colloidal Fe 3 O 4 particles with an oleic acid coating of 0.01% to 0.2% and observed thermal conductivity from 20 to 80℃. Another research by Gavali et al. [30] analyzed Fe 3 O 4 /water nanofluids with a 10 nm particle size and showed thermal conductivity improvement of about 200% at a volume concentration of 5%. There are still some difficulties in practicing Fe 3 O 4 as it agglomerates easily in water and has poor dispersion for photo-thermal energy conversion. That is because of the large surface to volume ratio and the strong dipole-dipole interface between the nanoparticles [31].Researchers have focused on properties of magnetite (Fe 3 O 4 ) nanofluids, have attracted attention because of the wide range of purposes in the energy disciplines such as CO 2 capture [27] and thermal absorption systems and employed for direct absorption in collectors for solar radiation [28]. Wide-ranging photon absorption cross-section, and powerful intermolecular bonds, economical, and environmentally friendly are the main characteristics of Fe 3 O 4 . Fertman et al. [29] studied hydrocarbon-based magnetic fluids, including colloidal Fe 3 O 4 particles with an oleic acid coating of 0.01% to 0.2% and observed thermal conductivity from 20 to 80℃. Another research by Gavali et al. [30] analyzed Fe 3 O 4 /water nanofluids with a 10 nm particle size and showed thermal conductivity improvement of about 200% at a volume concentration of 5%. There are still some difficulties in practicing Fe 3 O 4 as it agglomerates easily in water and has poor dispersion for photo-thermal energy conversion. That is because of the large surface to volume ratio and the strong dipole-dipole interface between the nanoparticles [31].

Graphene introduces as a unique class of carbon nanomaterials. It shows quite favorable characteristics, outstanding mechanical strength, surface area with high electrical conductivity. It has been an excellent material to improve chemical, physical, and mechanical properties in various applications [32]. Graphene sheets are studied by many investigators to improve the heat transfer attributes of water-based fluids [33][34][35]. Novoselov and co-workers recognized it in 2004 as a family of a 2D carbon monolayer packed into a honeycomb structure that was considered to be a building block for carbonaceous materials such as graphite and carbon nanotubes [36,37]. In recent years, several publications have grown continuously addressing the application of graphene in electrochemical energystorage mechanisms such as lithium-ion batteries, sodium-ion batteries, electrochemical capacitors, and many more. Techniques such as mechanical exfoliation [37], SiC synthesis [38], and bottom-up synthesis from specified organic precursors [39], inevitably reduce the graphene usage to significant research and applications, because of the restricted scalability and costly production expenses. Similarly, a wellestablished procedure in production is the deposition of hydrocarbons by chemical vapor [38], which is J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f not appropriate for storing electrochemical energy on an extensive scale production of graphene [39]. The deposition of chemical vapor has been described as an effective approach to assemble vertically oriented graphene nanosheets [40], besides the low packing density of the graphene [41]. Graphene oxide needs to reduce chemically, thermally, electromechanically processes to restore the π system, which is the quality for conductive graphene [42,43]. Graphene oxide-iron oxide (GO-Fe 3 O 4 ) nanocomposites have been prepared into GO sheets in basic solution by co-precipitating iron salts. Chandra et al. [44] [45]. Said et al. [4] investigated the stability and thermophysical properties of CNF, FCNF, rGO, and rGO coated over F-CNF (F-CNF/rGO) and the most stable sample was observed to be F-CNF/rGO showing zeta potential value of -45 mV and -33.4 mV on the 1st and 180th day respectively, without agglomeration. The Fe 3 O 4 /CRG nanocomposite was synthesized through the reduction of Fe 3 O 4 /GO by Gao et al. [46] by heating aqueous solutions of FeCl 3 , GO, NaOH, and diethylene glycol at a temperature of 22 o C. The analytic modeling of chemically reduced graphene CRG and Fe 3 O 4 nanoparticles is observed [47,48]. Also, the mechanical milling of graphite oxide and Fe(acac) 3 mixture [49] are employed by fabricating Fe 3 O 4 /CRG nanocomposites. The low affinity of iron oxide nanoparticles is due to the reduction in binding positions for Fe 3 O 4 nanoparticles on the exposed surface of graphene.Graphene introduces as a unique class of carbon nanomaterials. It shows quite favorable characteristics, outstanding mechanical strength, surface area with high electrical conductivity. It has been an excellent material to improve chemical, physical, and mechanical properties in various applications [32]. Graphene sheets are studied by many investigators to improve the heat transfer attributes of water-based fluids [33][34][35]. Novoselov and co-workers recognized it in 2004 as a family of a 2D carbon monolayer packed into a honeycomb structure that was considered to be a building block for carbonaceous materials such as graphite and carbon nanotubes [36,37]. In recent years, several publications have grown continuously addressing the application of graphene in electrochemical energystorage mechanisms such as lithium-ion batteries, sodium-ion batteries, electrochemical capacitors, and many more. Techniques such as mechanical exfoliation [37], SiC synthesis [38], and bottom-up synthesis from specified organic precursors [39], inevitably reduce the graphene usage to significant research and applications, because of the restricted scalability and costly production expenses. Similarly, a wellestablished procedure in production is the deposition of hydrocarbons by chemical vapor [38], which is J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f not appropriate for storing electrochemical energy on an extensive scale production of graphene [39]. The deposition of chemical vapor has been described as an effective approach to assemble vertically oriented graphene nanosheets [40], besides the low packing density of the graphene [41]. Graphene oxide needs to reduce chemically, thermally, electromechanically processes to restore the π system, which is the quality for conductive graphene [42,43]. Graphene oxide-iron oxide (GO-Fe 3 O 4 ) nanocomposites have been prepared into GO sheets in basic solution by co-precipitating iron salts. Chandra et al. [44] [45]. Said et al. [4] investigated the stability and thermophysical properties of CNF, FCNF, rGO, and rGO coated over F-CNF (F-CNF/rGO) and the most stable sample was observed to be F-CNF/rGO showing zeta potential value of -45 mV and -33.4 mV on the 1st and 180th day respectively, without agglomeration. The Fe 3 O 4 /CRG nanocomposite was synthesized through the reduction of Fe 3 O 4 /GO by Gao et al. [46] by heating aqueous solutions of FeCl 3 , GO, NaOH, and diethylene glycol at a temperature of 22 o C. The analytic modeling of chemically reduced graphene CRG and Fe 3 O 4 nanoparticles is observed [47,48]. Also, the mechanical milling of graphite oxide and Fe(acac) 3 mixture [49] are employed by fabricating Fe 3 O 4 /CRG nanocomposites. The low affinity of iron oxide nanoparticles is due to the reduction in binding positions for Fe 3 O 4 nanoparticles on the exposed surface of graphene.

The thermophysical characteristics of kerosene-based nanofluid with Fe 3 O 4 and graphene nanoparticles have been studied by Askari et al. [50], showing 31% enhancement at 50°C with 1% particle loading and 66% improvement in the heat transfer rate at a Reynolds number of 4553. Another investigation to prepare a stable graphene/ Fe 3 O 4 nanofluid was examined by Mehrauli et al. [51] and Sadeghinezhad et al.The thermophysical characteristics of kerosene-based nanofluid with Fe 3 O 4 and graphene nanoparticles have been studied by Askari et al. [50], showing 31% enhancement at 50°C with 1% particle loading and 66% improvement in the heat transfer rate at a Reynolds number of 4553. Another investigation to prepare a stable graphene/ Fe 3 O 4 nanofluid was examined by Mehrauli et al. [51] and Sadeghinezhad et al.

[52] by using tannic acid to reduce and stabilize to examine heat transfer performance, and thermal conductivity were improved by 11% at 40°C. Harandi et al. [53] examined the effects of volume J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f concentration, and temperature of f-MWCNTs-Fe 3 O 4 /EG nanofluid and thermal conductivity were enhanced by higher concentration and temperature. The highest was recorded 30% improvement in thermal conductivity at 50°C and 2.3% concentration. The single-layer graphene has captivated attention as its thermal conductivity has been reported far higher as compared to carbon nanotubes. The thermal conductivity of graphene was observed experimentally at 20°C of about 4800-5300 W/m.K [54]. Due to its outstanding thermal conductivity, graphene has drawn huge interest as a solid additive. Graphene influences heat transfer applications due to weak dispersion stability and on surface hydrophilic groups resulting in better dispersion while the thermal conductivity is improved as in comparison to base fluids.[52] by using tannic acid to reduce and stabilize to examine heat transfer performance, and thermal conductivity were improved by 11% at 40°C. Harandi et al. [53] examined the effects of volume J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f concentration, and temperature of f-MWCNTs-Fe 3 O 4 /EG nanofluid and thermal conductivity were enhanced by higher concentration and temperature. The highest was recorded 30% improvement in thermal conductivity at 50°C and 2.3% concentration. The single-layer graphene has captivated attention as its thermal conductivity has been reported far higher as compared to carbon nanotubes. The thermal conductivity of graphene was observed experimentally at 20°C of about 4800-5300 W/m.K [54]. Due to its outstanding thermal conductivity, graphene has drawn huge interest as a solid additive. Graphene influences heat transfer applications due to weak dispersion stability and on surface hydrophilic groups resulting in better dispersion while the thermal conductivity is improved as in comparison to base fluids.

Another study showed that acid behavior could stop carbon nanotubes and graphene from accumulating by mechanical mixing, however, no improvement in the thermal conductivity was observed due to acid damage in the graphene structure [55,56]. Graphene nanosheets are prevented from stacking due to the attachment of metal oxide nanoparticles, and this approach is also implemented in other applications such as batteries and supercapacitors. The improvement in metal oxide/graphene composites as solid additives to form different kinds of nanofluids with high thermal conductivity and better stability is still in progress. This paper presents characterization, thermal conductivity, and stability of ternary rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 hybrid nanofluid, which is reported for the first time in literature. The nanocomposites were synthesized by the sol-gel method, and the characterization of hybrid nanofluids has been explained. Then thermophysical properties of rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 nanofluid, including stability and thermal conductivity of nanofluid, have been investigated at various concentrations of 0.01-0.25 mass% and various temperatures of 25-30-40˚C. Stable nanofluids with enhanced thermal conductivity were obtained. The findings from this work can be utilized for heat transfer applications, and the proposed nanofluid can be used for both heating and cooling applications with long term stability.Another study showed that acid behavior could stop carbon nanotubes and graphene from accumulating by mechanical mixing, however, no improvement in the thermal conductivity was observed due to acid damage in the graphene structure [55,56]. Graphene nanosheets are prevented from stacking due to the attachment of metal oxide nanoparticles, and this approach is also implemented in other applications such as batteries and supercapacitors. The improvement in metal oxide/graphene composites as solid additives to form different kinds of nanofluids with high thermal conductivity and better stability is still in progress. This paper presents characterization, thermal conductivity, and stability of ternary rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 hybrid nanofluid, which is reported for the first time in literature. The nanocomposites were synthesized by the sol-gel method, and the characterization of hybrid nanofluids has been explained. Then thermophysical properties of rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 nanofluid, including stability and thermal conductivity of nanofluid, have been investigated at various concentrations of 0.01-0.25 mass% and various temperatures of 25-30-40˚C. Stable nanofluids with enhanced thermal conductivity were obtained. The findings from this work can be utilized for heat transfer applications, and the proposed nanofluid can be used for both heating and cooling applications with long term stability.
Journal Pre-proofJournal Pre-proof

To synthesize TiO 2 nanoparticles, titanium (IV) butoxide (Sigma Aldrich) was utilized as a precursor.To synthesize TiO 2 nanoparticles, titanium (IV) butoxide (Sigma Aldrich) was utilized as a precursor.

Graphite powder (100 mesh, ≥75% min), sulfuric acid (H 2 SO 4 ), hydrochloric acid (HCl), orthophosphoric acid (H 3 PO 4 ), ethylene glycol (C 2 H 6 O 2 ), hydrogen peroxide 30% (H 2 O 2 ) and potassium permanganate (KMnO 4 ) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich constituted the other chemicals, utilized to prepare the nanocomposite. All chemicals were utilized without performing additional purification.Graphite powder (100 mesh, ≥75% min), sulfuric acid (H 2 SO 4 ), hydrochloric acid (HCl), orthophosphoric acid (H 3 PO 4 ), ethylene glycol (C 2 H 6 O 2 ), hydrogen peroxide 30% (H 2 O 2 ) and potassium permanganate (KMnO 4 ) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich constituted the other chemicals, utilized to prepare the nanocomposite. All chemicals were utilized without performing additional purification.

Natural graphite powder was utilized for the synthesis of rGO by employing the modified Hummers method, further utilized for the preparation of ternary nanocomposites [57,58]. The synthesis of Fe 3 O 4 nanoparticles was realized as a result of FeSO 4 and FeCl 3 thermal decomposition in EG with ethanolamine and sodium acetate (NaAc) [59,60]. As a result, both Fe 3 O 4 and GO nanoparticles were dried at 60 ° C for an average of 24 hours, and the powder forms were made ready for sol-gel process to form a triple nanocomposite.Natural graphite powder was utilized for the synthesis of rGO by employing the modified Hummers method, further utilized for the preparation of ternary nanocomposites [57,58]. The synthesis of Fe 3 O 4 nanoparticles was realized as a result of FeSO 4 and FeCl 3 thermal decomposition in EG with ethanolamine and sodium acetate (NaAc) [59,60]. As a result, both Fe 3 O 4 and GO nanoparticles were dried at 60 ° C for an average of 24 hours, and the powder forms were made ready for sol-gel process to form a triple nanocomposite.

The straightforward sol-gel approach was employed to synthesize ternary rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 nanocomposites [61]. To prepare nanocomposites, an equal weight ratio of all the components was taken.The straightforward sol-gel approach was employed to synthesize ternary rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 nanocomposites [61]. To prepare nanocomposites, an equal weight ratio of all the components was taken.

In brief, during the synthesis, the dispersion of 0.65 g of GO in 260 mL of ethanol and 0.65 g of Fe 3 O 4 in 260 mL of ethanol was carried out separately. The sonication of the mentioned solutions was performed for a period of 1 h. Following the process of prob sonication, the mixing of both solutions was carried out, and then 65 ml of titanium (IV) butoxide was added. The further stirring of the solution in question was performed for the following 1 h. In the end, a Teflon coated stainless steel autoclave with 200 mL was used where the solution was placed under nitrogen purging and heated for a duration of 10 h at a temperature of 180 ˚C. After the reaction was completed, a precipitate of greyish color was acquired, and J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f it was cleaned thrice using ethanol and water to eliminate impurities. For the duration of 10 h, the prepared nanocomposite was then soaked up in a vacuum oven at a temperature of 60 ˚C.In brief, during the synthesis, the dispersion of 0.65 g of GO in 260 mL of ethanol and 0.65 g of Fe 3 O 4 in 260 mL of ethanol was carried out separately. The sonication of the mentioned solutions was performed for a period of 1 h. Following the process of prob sonication, the mixing of both solutions was carried out, and then 65 ml of titanium (IV) butoxide was added. The further stirring of the solution in question was performed for the following 1 h. In the end, a Teflon coated stainless steel autoclave with 200 mL was used where the solution was placed under nitrogen purging and heated for a duration of 10 h at a temperature of 180 ˚C. After the reaction was completed, a precipitate of greyish color was acquired, and J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f it was cleaned thrice using ethanol and water to eliminate impurities. For the duration of 10 h, the prepared nanocomposite was then soaked up in a vacuum oven at a temperature of 60 ˚C.

X-ray diffraction (XRD: Rigaku DMAX IIIC) was investigated for structural analysis of the nanocomposites synthesized. A scanning electron microscope (SEM: TESCAN MIRA3 XMU) was utilized to assess the surface morphology of ternary nanocomposites. The pressing of all specimens into potassium bromide pellets was performed, and they were utilized for the examination of the functional groups of the nanocomposite by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR: Bruker: Tensor II) spectrophotometer in the range of 4000-500 cm -1 . Zeta potential analyzer (Malvern Instruments, UK) was used to measure stability values.X-ray diffraction (XRD: Rigaku DMAX IIIC) was investigated for structural analysis of the nanocomposites synthesized. A scanning electron microscope (SEM: TESCAN MIRA3 XMU) was utilized to assess the surface morphology of ternary nanocomposites. The pressing of all specimens into potassium bromide pellets was performed, and they were utilized for the examination of the functional groups of the nanocomposite by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR: Bruker: Tensor II) spectrophotometer in the range of 4000-500 cm -1 . Zeta potential analyzer (Malvern Instruments, UK) was used to measure stability values.

The dispersion of the resulting ternary nanocomposites in EG was carried out at various concentrations of 0.01-0.25 mass% and various temperatures of 25 to 60 ˚C for the uniform dispersion of nanoparticles and acquiring stable nanofluids by a 750-W ultrasonic mixer (Sonics & Materials Inc., USA) for the ultrasonication duration of 60 minutes. The ultrasonic technique especially prob ultrasonication is one of the best ways to obtain smaller sizes nanoparticles or even discrete nanoparticles. The chemical and physical properties for EG are shown in Table 1.The dispersion of the resulting ternary nanocomposites in EG was carried out at various concentrations of 0.01-0.25 mass% and various temperatures of 25 to 60 ˚C for the uniform dispersion of nanoparticles and acquiring stable nanofluids by a 750-W ultrasonic mixer (Sonics & Materials Inc., USA) for the ultrasonication duration of 60 minutes. The ultrasonic technique especially prob ultrasonication is one of the best ways to obtain smaller sizes nanoparticles or even discrete nanoparticles. The chemical and physical properties for EG are shown in Table 1.

To examine thermal conductivity, the preparation of nanocomposites at different concentrations was performed. A thermal conductivity analyzer (Decagon KD2 Pro, ±5%) that works with the technique of transient hot-wire method (THW) based on the ASTM D7896 standard [62] is used to measure the thermal conductivity of produced rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 hybrid nanofluids at 25 °C, 30 °C, 40 °C, 50 °C, 60 °C. The calibration of the sensor needle (KS-1, which is in the range of 0.2-2 W/mK with an accuracy of ±5%.) was carried out first by measuring the thermal conductivity of distilled water and glycerin. The measured values for distilled water and glycerin were 0.611 and 0.292 W/mK, respectively, which agree J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f with the literature values of 0.613 and 0.285 W/mK respectively within ±5% accuracy [63]. After the probe of the instrument (KS-1) is completely inserted in the nanofluid tube, the analyzer is switched on at low power mode, thereby preventing convective currents [64]. A WiseBath (WB-11, witeg Labortechnik GmbH) water bath (Temperature range: Ambient+5℃~ 100℃, Accuracy: ±0.1℃) that include a filled with still water to supply uniform temperatures to the test tube are used to provide stable nanofluids. A sequence of calibrations were carried out using EG for the validation of the accuracy of the sensors. The measurements are carried out 40 min., after the system reached thermally steady-state conditions, and the average value obtained after 10 measurements is reported. The conductivity meter and water bath are shown in Fig. 1.To examine thermal conductivity, the preparation of nanocomposites at different concentrations was performed. A thermal conductivity analyzer (Decagon KD2 Pro, ±5%) that works with the technique of transient hot-wire method (THW) based on the ASTM D7896 standard [62] is used to measure the thermal conductivity of produced rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 hybrid nanofluids at 25 °C, 30 °C, 40 °C, 50 °C, 60 °C. The calibration of the sensor needle (KS-1, which is in the range of 0.2-2 W/mK with an accuracy of ±5%.) was carried out first by measuring the thermal conductivity of distilled water and glycerin. The measured values for distilled water and glycerin were 0.611 and 0.292 W/mK, respectively, which agree J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f with the literature values of 0.613 and 0.285 W/mK respectively within ±5% accuracy [63]. After the probe of the instrument (KS-1) is completely inserted in the nanofluid tube, the analyzer is switched on at low power mode, thereby preventing convective currents [64]. A WiseBath (WB-11, witeg Labortechnik GmbH) water bath (Temperature range: Ambient+5℃~ 100℃, Accuracy: ±0.1℃) that include a filled with still water to supply uniform temperatures to the test tube are used to provide stable nanofluids. A sequence of calibrations were carried out using EG for the validation of the accuracy of the sensors. The measurements are carried out 40 min., after the system reached thermally steady-state conditions, and the average value obtained after 10 measurements is reported. The conductivity meter and water bath are shown in Fig. 1.

To examine the functional groups that were attached to the nanocomposite surface, the recording of the FTIR spectra was performed in an interval of 4000-500 cm -1 . Fig. 2 presents the FTIR spectra of ternary nanocomposites and demonstrates the presence of different absorption peaks from the specimen. The GO surface involves a lot of functional groups, including hydroxyl (C-OH), epoxide (C-O-C), and carboxyl (COOH).To examine the functional groups that were attached to the nanocomposite surface, the recording of the FTIR spectra was performed in an interval of 4000-500 cm -1 . Fig. 2 presents the FTIR spectra of ternary nanocomposites and demonstrates the presence of different absorption peaks from the specimen. The GO surface involves a lot of functional groups, including hydroxyl (C-OH), epoxide (C-O-C), and carboxyl (COOH).

Here, the vibrational group at 1729 cm -1 originates from the C=O extending, which indicates GO deoxidization in the course of the solvothermal method. As is seen from Fig. 2, it is possible to attribute the IR absorption peaks at 1729 cm -1 of GO to carbonyl stretching vibration.Here, the vibrational group at 1729 cm -1 originates from the C=O extending, which indicates GO deoxidization in the course of the solvothermal method. As is seen from Fig. 2, it is possible to attribute the IR absorption peaks at 1729 cm -1 of GO to carbonyl stretching vibration.

Additionally, bands at 1564 cm -1 originating from the C=C vibration of aromatic rings, were observed in GO [65]. Furthermore, the broadband at 3430 cm -1 was attributed to the O-H stretching. Moreover, the nanocomposite also demonstrated a minor band at 2918 cm -1 , which was attributed to the extending J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f vibration of the CH 2 bond [66]. Interestingly, at 500-700 cm -1 wave number, two bond vibrations were present on the titanium dioxide/magnetite nanocomposite [67], which represented the overlapping between the Fe-O and Ti-O vibration. The band close to 700 cm -1 corresponded to the Ti-O stretching vibration. The results of this FTIR show that rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 nanocomposites have been well composted, which is indicated for each material used by the appearance of the absorption group for each material. formation, the wide anatase peak of TiO 2 at 25.5° overlaid the rGO's characteristic peak [68,69]. The J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f characteristic diffraction peak of GO is at 2θ = 11.2º [69]. Following the completion of the reaction, this peak disappeared, and the characteristic peak of rGO 2θ = 26º appeared. Thus, it has been shown that GO was reduced entirely to rGO. The results of this FTIR show that rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 nanocomposites have been well composted, which is indicated for each material used by the appearance of the absorption group for each material. formation, the wide anatase peak of TiO 2 at 25.5° overlaid the rGO's characteristic peak [68,69]. The J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f characteristic diffraction peak of GO is at 2θ = 11.2º [69]. Following the completion of the reaction, this peak disappeared, and the characteristic peak of rGO 2θ = 26º appeared. Thus, it has been shown that GO was reduced entirely to rGO. Since two peaks that they are TiO 2 and rGO overlap, the intensity of this peak is quite high in Fig.

The stability of nanoparticles in aqueous solution effectively improves heat transfer performance due to electrokinetic characteristics. Nanoparticles in the base fluid with greater surface charge density creates stronger repulsive forces similar to the charged particles. Usually, the stability of nanofluids can be measured by zeta potential, which is known as a potential difference between the hybrid nanoparticles and the base fluid (A thin layer of ions with an opposite charge to the layer of ions that naturaly coats it is drawn due to a small charge at the surface of a nanoparticle, which results in creating a double layer of ions, that moves through the liquid carried by the nanoparticle. Therefore, the nanoparticle moving through the suspension can be seen as coated with a stationary layer of the medium. The electric potential value, which is at the boundary of the formed double layer, between the layer grabbed by the nanoparticle and the suspension, is known as zeta potential) [70]. Stable nanofluids are evaluated with a zeta potential value of ±30-40 mV, while suspensions with a zeta potential ranges from ±40-60 mV have good stabilityThe stability of nanoparticles in aqueous solution effectively improves heat transfer performance due to electrokinetic characteristics. Nanoparticles in the base fluid with greater surface charge density creates stronger repulsive forces similar to the charged particles. Usually, the stability of nanofluids can be measured by zeta potential, which is known as a potential difference between the hybrid nanoparticles and the base fluid (A thin layer of ions with an opposite charge to the layer of ions that naturaly coats it is drawn due to a small charge at the surface of a nanoparticle, which results in creating a double layer of ions, that moves through the liquid carried by the nanoparticle. Therefore, the nanoparticle moving through the suspension can be seen as coated with a stationary layer of the medium. The electric potential value, which is at the boundary of the formed double layer, between the layer grabbed by the nanoparticle and the suspension, is known as zeta potential) [70]. Stable nanofluids are evaluated with a zeta potential value of ±30-40 mV, while suspensions with a zeta potential ranges from ±40-60 mV have good stability

Journal Pre-proof [12]. Zeta potential below ± 30 mV leads to poor stability, where the nanoparticles tend to agglomerate , as at such zeta potential values, nanoparticles find it challenging to resist the forces that work to conglomerate them in the base fluid. The zeta potential values of rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 /EG nanofluids with the concentration from 0.01 to 0.25 wt% were evaluated in the present study. Among different graphene types, GO consists of epoxide, hydroxyl, carboxyl, and carbonyl functional groups. These functional groups interacted with the solvent and increased the stability of nanofluid. The stability of graphene oxide has shown to be very good in a previous study [71]. Li et al. [72] showed that rGO were negatively charged (-35 mV ), and its stability was partially good.Journal Pre-proof [12]. The zeta potential values of rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 /EG nanofluids with the concentration from 0.01 to 0.25 wt% were evaluated in the present study. Among different graphene types, GO consists of epoxide, hydroxyl, carboxyl, and carbonyl functional groups. These functional groups interacted with the solvent and increased the stability of nanofluid. The stability of graphene oxide has shown to be very good in a previous study [71]. Li et al. The excellent stability of rGO-Fe Fig. 6, shows the thermal conductivity of EG compared with the data reported in the literature [73]. A good agreement was achieved between the data we obtained and that reported in the literature, with a maximum % error within the acceptable limits. The thermal conductivity of rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 at various concentrations with changing temperature is represented in Fig. 7. It was observed that the thermal J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f conductivity improved with the increase in particle loading and temperature. The nanofluids thermal conductivity is influenced by temperature and concentration by dispersing nanoparticles in the base fluid.The excellent stability of rGO-Fe Fig. 6, shows the thermal conductivity of EG compared with the data reported in the literature [73]. A good agreement was achieved between the data we obtained and that reported in the literature, with a maximum % error within the acceptable limits. The thermal conductivity of rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 at various concentrations with changing temperature is represented in Fig. 7. It was observed that the thermal J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f conductivity improved with the increase in particle loading and temperature. The nanofluids thermal conductivity is influenced by temperature and concentration by dispersing nanoparticles in the base fluid.

Therefore, the thickness of the solid-liquid interfacial layer (though the thickness of this interfacial layer is of the order of a nanometer, this nanolayer is considered to be of significant importance, and plays a vital role in heat transport from the nanoparticle to the adjust liquid) and the thermal conductivity improves the overall thermal conductivity of the nanofluid [74]. This is based on the following phenomenon, such as, when there is an increase in nanoparticle concentration, they become more adjacent to one another. The vicinity improves heat conduction and improves thermal conductivity because of electrons and phonons [75,76], this phenomenon is known as the propagation of lattice vibrations, where the phonons, due to random creation, move in random directions, which are further scattered by one another or by the defects. Due to the small interparticle distance in the nanofluids, even using a small concentration of the composite results in ballistic phonons [77]. Also, suspended nanoparticles in the base fluid increase with the temperature increase because of Brownian motion (enabling of direct solid-solid transport from one particle to another and influencing the particle clustering), and thus, the thermal conductivity significantly increases at high temperatures [78]. The improvement in thermal conductivity reaches up to 13.3% at 60 ℃ (shown in Fig. 9) when the particle loading concentration of rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 composite is 0.25 wt% compared to ethylene glycol base fluid as shown in Fig. 8. The outcomes of using rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 is because TiO 2 and Fe 3 O 4 nanoparticles fixed on the reduced graphene oxide surface, which prevents the graphene sheets from agglomeration, as single graphene sheets likely to agglomerate rapidly, because of strong van der Waals forces. Consequently, rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 /EG hybrid nanofluids present a substantial thermal conductivity improvement.Therefore, the thickness of the solid-liquid interfacial layer (though the thickness of this interfacial layer is of the order of a nanometer, this nanolayer is considered to be of significant importance, and plays a vital role in heat transport from the nanoparticle to the adjust liquid) and the thermal conductivity improves the overall thermal conductivity of the nanofluid [74]. This is based on the following phenomenon, such as, when there is an increase in nanoparticle concentration, they become more adjacent to one another. The vicinity improves heat conduction and improves thermal conductivity because of electrons and phonons [75,76], this phenomenon is known as the propagation of lattice vibrations, where the phonons, due to random creation, move in random directions, which are further scattered by one another or by the defects. Due to the small interparticle distance in the nanofluids, even using a small concentration of the composite results in ballistic phonons [77]. Also, suspended nanoparticles in the base fluid increase with the temperature increase because of Brownian motion (enabling of direct solid-solid transport from one particle to another and influencing the particle clustering), and thus, the thermal conductivity significantly increases at high temperatures [78]. The improvement in thermal conductivity reaches up to 13.3% at 60 ℃ (shown in Fig. 9) when the particle loading concentration of rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 composite is 0.25 wt% compared to ethylene glycol base fluid as shown in Fig. 8. The outcomes of using rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 is because TiO 2 and Fe 3 O 4 nanoparticles fixed on the reduced graphene oxide surface, which prevents the graphene sheets from agglomeration, as single graphene sheets likely to agglomerate rapidly, because of strong van der Waals forces. Consequently, rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 /EG hybrid nanofluids present a substantial thermal conductivity improvement.

In order to provide a comprehensive insight for the thermal conductivity of ternary hybrid nanofluid, a comparison between the studied ternary hybrid nanofluid and other hybrid as well as mono nanofluids, have been summarized in mV and +63.45 mV. Therefore, it can be concluded that using the rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 ternary hybrid nanoparticles suspended in EG can be an excellent candidate for heat transfer applications, both in terms of enhanced thermal conductivity and excellent long term stability. Fig. 10 shows the comparision of our ternary hybrid nanofluid with the Fe 3 O 4 nanoparticles suspended in different basefluids such as kerosene [82,83] and water [16,84]. Even though the compared studies used high volume fractions compared to our study, our samples showed promsing enhancement. Low-viscosity fluids permit particles to move more freely and rapidly interact with one another, which leads to an increase in the Brownian motion of nanoparticles in fluids; therefore water based nanofluids have higher thermal conductivity compared to EG based nanofluids. Therefore, rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 ternary hybrid nanoparticles can also be investigated in water as a basefluid for better thermal conductivity and stability.In order to provide a comprehensive insight for the thermal conductivity of ternary hybrid nanofluid, a comparison between the studied ternary hybrid nanofluid and other hybrid as well as mono nanofluids, have been summarized in mV and +63.45 mV. Therefore, it can be concluded that using the rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 ternary hybrid nanoparticles suspended in EG can be an excellent candidate for heat transfer applications, both in terms of enhanced thermal conductivity and excellent long term stability. Fig. 10 shows the comparision of our ternary hybrid nanofluid with the Fe 3 O 4 nanoparticles suspended in different basefluids such as kerosene [82,83] and water [16,84]. Even though the compared studies used high volume fractions compared to our study, our samples showed promsing enhancement. Low-viscosity fluids permit particles to move more freely and rapidly interact with one another, which leads to an increase in the Brownian motion of nanoparticles in fluids; therefore water based nanofluids have higher thermal conductivity compared to EG based nanofluids. Therefore, rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 ternary hybrid nanoparticles can also be investigated in water as a basefluid for better thermal conductivity and stability.

Figures [11][12][13][14][15] displays the relationship between the experimental values and regression analysis for thermal conductivity of rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 /EG nanofluids with different concentrations ranging from 0.01% to 0.25% at 25 ℃, 30 ℃, 40 ℃, 50 ℃, and 60 ℃. There is a requirement for correlations to precisely calculate nanofluids thermal conductivity at different temperatures by different scholars [89,90]. The linear regression analysis was studied for fitting experimental data, results in the equation ( 1) below:Figures [11][12][13][14][15] displays the relationship between the experimental values and regression analysis for thermal conductivity of rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 /EG nanofluids with different concentrations ranging from 0.01% to 0.25% at 25 ℃, 30 ℃, 40 ℃, 50 ℃, and 60 ℃. There is a requirement for correlations to precisely calculate nanofluids thermal conductivity at different temperatures by different scholars [89,90]. The linear regression analysis was studied for fitting experimental data, results in the equation ( 1) below:

It can be observed from the figures [11][12][13][14][15] that the trend is almost linear with convergence to the origin.It can be observed from the figures [11][12][13][14][15] that the trend is almost linear with convergence to the origin.

It is following the experimental fittings. As the concentration increases, the thermal conductivity improves. When the R 2 reaches a value closer to 1, it means that the model used can predict the values in a better way and is considered reliable. The R 2 also is known as COD (coefficient of determination) is a numerical approach suitable for linear regression. The best R 2 (Coefficient of Determination-COD) estimated at 25 ℃, 30 ℃, 40 ℃, 50 ℃, and 60 ℃ was 95.6%, 98.2%, 95.4%, 97.6%, and 99.0 % which results in a good agreement that fits the experimental data perfectly. The model showed that R 2 >95%, which should ensure the reliability of the proposed regression models here, that can be utilized to predict the thermal conductivity for the investigated hybrid nanofluid at their respective temperatures and concentrations. In most studies targeted nanofluids thermal conductivity. From different nanofluids, our investigated EG nanofluids samples showed increased thermal conductivity as compared to EG as a basefluid, and it increased considerably by an increase in nanoparticle mass concentration. Furthermore, scattered data have been reported by different researchers. Some reports by some researchers for lower concentrations reported greater improvement in thermal conductivity, while others examined a slight increase [22]. Our tested samples showed a maximum improvement of 13.3 % at 60 ℃ for 0.25 wt.% concentration of the rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 composite illustrated in Fig. 7, which follows similar patterns as reported in the literature [70]. Thermal conductivity enhancement at different concentrations for rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 /EG nanofluid for the prepared samples is reported in Fig. 7. The increase in particle loading concentration and temperature showed an increment in thermal conductivity.It is following the experimental fittings. The best R 2 (Coefficient of Determination-COD) estimated at 25 ℃, 30 ℃, 40 ℃, 50 ℃, and 60 ℃ was 95.6%, 98.2%, 95.4%, 97.6%, and 99.0 % which results in a good agreement that fits the experimental data perfectly. The model showed that R 2 >95%, which should ensure the reliability of the proposed regression models here, that can be utilized to predict the thermal conductivity for the investigated hybrid nanofluid at their respective temperatures and concentrations. In most studies targeted nanofluids thermal conductivity. From different nanofluids, our investigated EG nanofluids samples showed increased thermal conductivity as compared to EG as a basefluid, and it increased considerably by an increase in nanoparticle mass concentration. Furthermore, scattered data have been reported by different researchers. Some reports by some researchers for lower concentrations reported greater improvement in thermal conductivity, while others examined a slight increase [22]. Our tested samples showed a maximum improvement of 13.3 % at 60 ℃ for 0.25 wt.% concentration of the rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 composite illustrated in Fig. 7, which follows similar patterns as reported in the literature [70]. Thermal conductivity enhancement at different concentrations for rGO-Fe 3 O 4 -TiO 2 /EG nanofluid for the prepared samples is reported in Fig. 7. The increase in particle loading concentration and temperature showed an increment in thermal conductivity.

Limited literature on convective heat transfer of nanofluids is reported in the literature, compared to the effect of particle loading on the increment of thermal conductivity [91]. However, numerous studies reported are on EG/W mixture based nanofluids compared to pure EG [3]. The reason for choosing the EG/H 2 O solution rather than pure ethyl glycol is to keep a lower viscosity and higher conduction as well [17]. Most review papers reported that nanofluids showed higher enhancement of conventional heat transfer performance (coefficient) that improves higher particle loading as well as the raise in Reynolds number and mass flow rate. For turbulent flow regimes, the heat transfer of nanofluids is even more obvious [92]. Even though a few studies stated a decrease of the convective heat transfer, however, nanofluids in any flow can do better in terms of heat transfer in contrast to their basefluids [93].Limited literature on convective heat transfer of nanofluids is reported in the literature, compared to the effect of particle loading on the increment of thermal conductivity [91]. However, numerous studies reported are on EG/W mixture based nanofluids compared to pure EG [3]. The reason for choosing the EG/H 2 O solution rather than pure ethyl glycol is to keep a lower viscosity and higher conduction as well [17]. Most review papers reported that nanofluids showed higher enhancement of conventional heat transfer performance (coefficient) that improves higher particle loading as well as the raise in Reynolds number and mass flow rate. For turbulent flow regimes, the heat transfer of nanofluids is even more obvious [92]. Even though a few studies stated a decrease of the convective heat transfer, however, nanofluids in any flow can do better in terms of heat transfer in contrast to their basefluids [93].

Nevertheless, definite knowledge of convective heat transfer mechanisms is still a hot topic of research.Nevertheless, definite knowledge of convective heat transfer mechanisms is still a hot topic of research.

Therefore, further organized experimental and scientific researches are required for the thermal characterization and nanofluids heat transfer mechanism (mono or hybrid). Another area that still requires J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f further investigations, is to come up with novel equations that can be used to predict the thermophysical properties of the hybrid nanofluids. In order to validate these equations, a lot of experimental work on the thermophysical properties needs to be carried out, so reliable models could be proposed.Therefore, further organized experimental and scientific researches are required for the thermal characterization and nanofluids heat transfer mechanism (mono or hybrid). Another area that still requires J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f further investigations, is to come up with novel equations that can be used to predict the thermophysical properties of the hybrid nanofluids. In order to validate these equations, a lot of experimental work on the thermophysical properties needs to be carried out, so reliable models could be proposed.

In the present research, characterization, stability, and thermal conductivity of rGO-Fe 50 ℃, and 60 ℃ was 95.6%, 98.2%, 95.4%, 97.6%, and 99.0 %, which results in a good agreement that fits the experimental data perfectly. The findings from this work can be utilized for heat transfer applications, and the proposed nanofluid can be used for both heating and cooling applications with long term stability, as well as for the prepared ternary hybrid nanoparticles shows a magnetic behavior which is an additional advantage [94]. These prepared ternary hybrid nanoparticles are not only limited to engineering applications but can also be used for biomedical applications [95].In the present research, characterization, stability, and thermal conductivity of rGO-Fe 50 ℃, and 60 ℃ was 95.6%, 98.2%, 95.4%, 97.6%, and 99.0 %, which results in a good agreement that fits the experimental data perfectly. These prepared ternary hybrid nanoparticles are not only limited to engineering applications but can also be used for biomedical applications [95].
